articles.headline: Puzzling Death of a Prosecutor Grips Argentina
articles.snippet: Alberto Nisman, a federal prosecutor who was found dead in his home, had accused top Argentine officials of conspiring with Iran to cover up responsibility for the 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center in Buenos Aires.
articles.abstract: Alberto Nisman, a federal prosecutor who was found dead in his home, had accused top Argentine officials of conspiring with Iran to cover up responsibility for the 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center in Buenos Aires.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Police sentries guarded the federal prosecutor’s luxury high-rise building. His door on the 13th floor had been locked from the inside, and a gun with a spent cartridge was found on the floor near his body. There was no suicide note.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Gilbert and Simon Romero

articles.headline: On to Plan B as Oil Work Stalls in Texas
articles.snippet: Many residents of Midland, a community dependent on oil drilling, already have their backup plans in place as work starts to dry up.
articles.abstract: Many residents of Midland, a community dependent on oil drilling, already have their backup plans in place as work starts to dry up.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIDLAND, Tex. — With oil prices plummeting by more than 50 percent since June, the gleeful mood of recent years has turned glum here in West Texas as the frenzy of shale oil drilling has come to a screeching halt.

articles.headline: Movie Studio by Amazon for Screens Big and Small
articles.snippet: The online retailing giant signaled its broader ambitions to revolutionize the traditional system used to shepherd movies from the theaters to home screens.
articles.abstract: The online retailing giant signaled its broader ambitions to revolutionize the traditional system used to shepherd movies from the theaters to home screens.
articles.lead_paragraph: First the small screen, now the big screen. Amazon’s entertainment ambitions come in all sizes.

articles.headline: U.S. Signals Shift on How to End Syrian Civil War
articles.snippet: American support for two diplomatic initiatives in Syria underscores the West’s quiet retreat from its demand that Bashar al-Assad step down immediately.
articles.abstract: American support for two diplomatic initiatives in Syria underscores the West’s quiet retreat from its demand that Bashar al-Assad step down immediately.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — American support for a pair of diplomatic initiatives in Syria underscores the shifting views of how to end the civil war there and the West’s quiet retreat from its demand that the country’s president, Bashar al-Assad, step down immediately.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Shifting Politics of Net Neutrality Debate Ahead of F.C.C. Vote
articles.snippet: A simple fight over big government versus small has put Republicans in the awkward position of defending cable giants, one of the nation’s most maligned industries.
articles.abstract: A simple fight over big government versus small has put Republicans in the awkward position of defending cable giants, one of the nation’s most maligned industries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last November, when President Obama proposed strict rules to prevent broadband companies from blocking or intentionally slowing down the web, Republicans pounced on what they called yet another heavy-handed liberal proposal. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas pronounced the regulations “Obamacare for the Internet.”

articles.headline: Debates at Davos Get Around to Gay Rights
articles.snippet: While Davos has long hosted controversial conversations, the issue of gay rights had seemed off limits at the World Economic Forum. This year, it’s on the official agenda.
articles.abstract: While Davos has long hosted controversial conversations, the issue of gay rights had seemed off limits at the World Economic Forum. This year, it’s on the official agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: The World Economic Forum annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland, which begins this week, has been a top venue for controversial conversations over the years. Israelis and Palestinians have debated, for example, and luminaries from the public and private sectors have faced off on big topics like climate change, inequality and gender diversity.

articles.headline: As Growth Slows, China Pins Hopes on Consumer Spending
articles.snippet: Beijing, which reported growth of 7.4 percent for 2014, below its target of 7.5 percent, is trying to reduce its dependence on credit-fueled investment and government spending.
articles.abstract: Beijing, which reported growth of 7.4 percent for 2014, below its target of 7.5 percent, is trying to reduce its dependence on credit-fueled investment and government spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As demand for exports slips and the real estate sector cools, China has been looking to consumers to help pick up the slack. But the country’s slowing growth will complicate those plans.

articles.headline: Sorority Anti-Rape Idea: Drinking on Own Turf
articles.snippet: For decades, national sororities have banned alcohol, but amid debate over how to address sexual assaults, many of them at fraternity parties, female students are questioning that policy.
articles.abstract: For decades, national sororities have banned alcohol, but amid debate over how to address sexual assaults, many of them at fraternity parties, female students are questioning that policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Walking past some fraternity parties on the George Washington University campus Saturday night, Sivan Sherriffe wondered about a longstanding tradition at her school and colleges nationwide.

articles.headline: Well Before Scandals, Cosby’s Wife Faulted Media Treatment of Blacks
articles.snippet: Camille Cosby, Bill Cosby’s wife of nearly 51 years, has spoken out for decades against images of African-Americans as seen on television and in other media.
articles.abstract: Camille Cosby, Bill Cosby’s wife of nearly 51 years, has spoken out for decades against images of African-Americans as seen on television and in other media.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill Cosby’s public defenders have not been numerous of late, but they have included some serious, credible people like Whoopi Goldberg, Ben Vereen and, most recently, Phylicia Rashad — his wife on television for more than a decade — who expressed her full support for him as he confronted accusations that he was a serial sexual predator.
articles.byline: By Serge F. Kovaleski and Colin Moynihan

articles.headline: In State of the Union Address, Obama Is to Move Past Hardship and Reset Goals
articles.snippet: President Obama is expected to use Tuesday’s State of the Union address to urge action on issues deferred by the nation’s economic struggles in recent years.
articles.abstract: President Obama is expected to use Tuesday’s State of the Union address to urge action on issues deferred by the nation’s economic struggles in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the American job market surging to life, President Obama plans to use his State of the Union address on Tuesday night to effectively declare victory over the economic hard times that dominated his first six years in office and advocate using the nation’s healthier finances to tackle long-deferred issues like education and income inequality.

articles.headline: ‘Koch Primary’ Tests Hopefuls In the G.O.P.
articles.snippet: The competition among Republican presidential hopefuls for the support of the Koch brothers heats up this week at an invitation-only seminar that kicks off the “Koch primary.”
articles.abstract: The competition among Republican presidential hopefuls for the support of the Koch brothers heats up this week at an invitation-only seminar that kicks off the “Koch primary.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky went to Kansas last year to campaign for Gov. Sam Brownback, he quietly requested a private meeting with the oil billionaire Charles G. Koch in his Wichita headquarters.

articles.headline: Greek Left’s New Issue: All-Inclusive Resorts
articles.snippet: Hoteliers and others are worried by proposals that include a possible increase in the value-added tax and a plan to curb all-inclusive resort deals.
articles.abstract: Hoteliers and others are worried by proposals that include a possible increase in the value-added tax and a plan to curb all-inclusive resort deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — David Phillips has been vacationing for over a decade at the Electra Palace Hotel on the island of Rhodes.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim and Aggelos Petropoulos
